sentences.sentence: Was 2021 a good year for freedom-loving conservatives?
At first glance, certainly not.
Overzealous virus control efforts by governments carried on into a second year, and despite the prevalence of vaccines, governments are again expanding restrictions as the year comes to a close.
The fire of wokeism continues to ravage a free and tolerant society, blazing especially hot in the education system.
Inflation is close to a 20-year high, and federal spending by the Liberals continues unabated - and unchecked by an ineffective Conservative Party.

Speaking of Conservatives: both federally and in Ontario they spent the year pursuing newfound enthusiasms for labour regulation, unionization, and industrial policy, while other deleterious interventions were everywhere reflected in their policy agendas.The private sector, unfortunately, did more to hasten the decline of freedom than reverse it.
In the business community, there has been a significant rise in the popularity of doctrines holding that public "stakeholders" have claims on the private property of shareholders.

Something called the Coalition for a Better Future was formed and expanded to over 120 member organizations, including the country's most powerful business and industry associations, prominent think tanks, non-profits, and community organizations.

The coalition advocates(https://financialpost.com/opinion/matthew-lau-this-week-in-ottawa-the-business-coalition-for-national-economic-planning) national economic planning and the politicization of corporate activity with the intention of transforming society to achieve "inclusive, sustainable economic growth" - in other words, to increase economic equality and demonstrate climate concern.Fortunately, despite the bad news, 2021 also brought reasons for optimism.
The woke fire's increasing intensity has at least provoked public alarm and brought fire-controllers into action.

The non-woke population's all but universal derision for allowing biologically male athletes to compete against females, smash records and win competitions by outlandish margins, no longer remains unexpressed.

The Macdonald-Laurier Institute earlier this month published a serious, substantial paper(https://www.macdonaldlaurier.ca/biology-fairness-trans-inclusion-sport-paper/ ) arguing that "gender identity (a subjective concept) is a poor basis for sports categories.
It is biological sex (an objective fact) which drives the inherent differences in athletic advantage, and which makes sex-based categories in sport necessary."
Case in point: the recent story of University of Pennsylvania swimmer, Lia Thomas, formerly mediocre male swimmer, Will Thomas, who has destroyed the competition racing as a woman.
Said a female swimming teammate(https://www.nationalreview.com/corner/teammate-of-trans-swimmer-speaks-out/): "Pretty much everyone individually has spoken to our coaches about not liking this.

"Meanwhile, there have been mounting stories of preposterous wokeness in the government-run education system: a draft copy of Ontario's school curriculum including a preamble, since removed(https://nationalpost.com/pmn/news-pmn/canada-news-pmn/ontario-removes-anti-racism-text-from-math-curriculum-preamble), claiming that mathematics has been used to normalize racism and colonialism; a teachers' union in Halton weighing votes(https://nationalpost.com/news/canada/ontario-teachers-union-implements-controversial-weighted-voting-system-to-increase-minority-representation) by skin colour; the Toronto District School Board initially cancelling(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/rex-murphy-toronto-school-boards-profoundly-ignorant-rejection-of-book-club-event-with-nobel-prize-winner) a book club event with 2018 Peace Nobelist and ISIS victim Nadia Murad over concerns about Islamophobia; and so on.
Such stories, along with declining educational standards, have made the government-run school system significantly more disreputable.

This has not yet translated into policies expanding school choice, but if families increasingly demand alternatives to government-run schools, that may only be a matter of time.Matthew Lau: Some hidden inflation with your fries?

(https://financialpost.com/opinion/matthew-lau-some-hidden-inflation-with-your-fries)Matthew Lau: The trouble with Ontario's new auto strategy: It exists(https://financialpost.com/opinion/matthew-lau-the-trouble-with-ontarios-new-auto-strategy-it-exists)Matthew Lau: How not to help the wretched of the Earth(https://financialpost.com/opinion/matthew-lau-how-not-to-help-the-wretched-of-the-earth)In economic policy, as in education, things have gotten worse instead of better.
But here, too, there is a potential silver lining.
To the extent that unfortunate economic outcomes are clearly attributable to bad government policies, they should bring discredit upon the politicians imposing those policies.

As rising public debt, lethargic growth, and high inflation cause significant economic distress, sensible Canadians will increasingly look askance upon woke budgeting, expensive climate piety, enthusiasm for raising taxes, and general fiscal profligacy.As for the socialist doctrines that swept over the business community in 2021, culminating with Mark Carney being declared one of two winners of this year's National Business Book Award, the reasons for optimism may be few.

But the opposition to the business community's plunge into climate alarmism, fixation on progressive notions of "social responsibility," and aspirations to collaborate with governments on central planning initiatives, if not exactly widespread, at least continues in free-market quarters, including here at FP Comment and at the Fraser Institute(https://www.fraserinstitute.org/blogs/central-planning-by-business-is-still-central-planning).So, while 2021 was no great year for freedom, advocacy for freedom and free markets carries on, and the tide, at least in some important areas, may well be turning.
In the long run, progressive fantasies - about sports, mathematics, education, economics, and everything else - will run into the brick wall of reality.
It is only a question of when.
Early 2022 would be good.Matthew Lau is a Toronto writer.
@COPYRIGHT=© 2021 Postmedia Network Inc. All rights reserved.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
